Lung.description: The Lung meridian is associated with the Metal element, which governs organization, boundaries, and letting go. It relates to the emotion of grief and the process of release. The Lung is responsible for taking in pure qi from the air and dispersing it throughout the body.
characteristics: Controls skin and body hair (defensive qi)
balancing_practices: Working with grief and loss in healthy ways

Large Intestine.description: The Large Intestine meridian is the yang pair to the Lung meridian, also associated with the Metal element. It represents elimination, letting go, and making space for the new. It works in tandem with the Lungs to clear waste from the body.
characteristics: Extracts last bits of pure qi from food waste
Assists in the release of emotional waste
imbalance_symptoms: Difficulty letting go of the past

Stomach.description: The Stomach meridian is associated with the Earth element, which governs nourishment, stability, and centeredness. The Stomach receives food and begins the digestive process, transforming it into nutrients that can be absorbed.
characteristics: Responsible for receiving and ripening food
Creates the foundation for post-natal qi
Supports the spleen in nourishing the body

Spleen.description: The Spleen meridian is the yin Earth element meridian, working in partnership with the Stomach. It transforms food into energy and blood, distributing nourishment throughout the body. The Spleen governs our ability to digest not just food, but also experiences and information.
characteristics: Transforms food into qi and blood

Heart.description: The Heart meridian is associated with the Fire element, governing joy, love, and spiritual connection. The Heart is considered the Emperor in Chinese medicine, housing the Shen (spirit) and governing consciousness and mental activity.

Small Intestine.description: The Small Intestine meridian is the yang pair to the Heart meridian, associated with the Fire element. It sorts pure from impure, assimilating what is useful and eliminating what is not. This sorting function applies to both nutrients and ideas/experiences.
characteristics: Assists the Heart in clarity of mind
Manifests in the small intestine organ

Urinary Bladder.description: The Urinary Bladder meridian is associated with the Water element, governing resources, willpower, and reserves. The longest meridian in the body, it runs down the back along the spine, connecting to all major organ systems. It stores and excretes liquid waste.
characteristics: Governs the muscles and bones of the back
Receives fluids from the Small Intestine
Reflects the health of the nervous system
Manifests in the urinary bladder organ

Kidney.description: The Kidney meridian is the yin Water element meridian, considered the foundation of all yin and yang energies in the body. It stores our essential life force (Jing) and governs growth, reproduction, and development. The Kidneys are associated with willpower, courage, and wisdom.
characteristics: Grasps the qi from the lungs

Pericardium.description: The Pericardium meridian is associated with the Fire element, specifically the Ministerial Fire aspect. The Pericardium serves as the protector of the Heart, governing our boundaries in relationships and our capacity for intimacy while maintaining protection.
characteristics: Protects the Heart physically and emotionally
Controls boundaries in connection with others
imbalance_symptoms: Inappropriate boundaries (too rigid or too porous)

Triple Burner.description: The Triple Burner (or Triple Heater) meridian is the yang pair to the Pericardium, associated with the Fire element. Unlike other meridians, it doesn't correspond to a specific organ but rather coordinates the functions between three body regions or 'burners'. It regulates temperature, fluid distribution, and metabolic activities.
characteristics: Regulates the relationship between organ systems
Governs the transformation and movement of fluids
Manifests as the coordination between systems
balancing_practices: Harmonizing exercises that integrate body systems

Gallbladder.description: The Gallbladder meridian is associated with the Wood element, governing decisions, planning, and execution. The Gallbladder stores and releases bile, which symbolically relates to making clear judgments and having the courage to take action.
balancing_practices: Gentle stretching for tendons and sinews
Finding middle path between action and restraint

Liver.description: The Liver meridian is the yin Wood element meridian, governing the smooth flow of qi throughout the body. The Liver is responsible for planning and vision, and it stores blood during rest. It is closely connected to emotional flow and creative expression.
imbalance_symptoms: Difficulty planning or visualizing the future
balancing_practices: Practices that promote flexibility (physical and mental)

Conception Vessel.description: The Conception Vessel (Ren Mai) is one of the eight extraordinary meridians, running up the front midline of the body. It governs all yin energies and is known as the 'Sea of Yin'. It's deeply connected to creation, nourishment, and development.
characteristics: Connects to the uterus and genitals
Influences the anterior and interior aspects of the body
Supports the creation of new life and ideas

Governing Vessel.description: The Governing Vessel (Du Mai) is one of the eight extraordinary meridians, running up the back midline of the body along the spine. It governs all yang energies and is known as the 'Sea of Yang'. It's connected to our core strength, willpower, and autonomy.
characteristics: Controls the posterior and exterior aspects of the body
balancing_practices: Mindful attention to posture and alignment
